title: Falcons DT Grady Jarrett hopes to win ring that eluded his dad, Jessie Tuggle
text:
Falcons DT Grady Jarrett hopes to win ring that eluded his dad, Jessie Tuggle Falcons DT Grady Jarrett hopes that isn't case as he pursues ring that eluded his dad, Jessie Tuggle. Jones , USA TODAY Sports 6:22 p.m. ET Feb. 2, 2017 CLOSE x Share USA TODAY Sports' Tom Pelissero breaks down what to look out for from Houston as the New England Patriots and Atlanta Falcons prepare for Super Bowl LI. USA TODAY Sports Falcons DT Grady Jarrett made 48 tackles this season. (Photo: Brett Davis, USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
HOUSTON — Jessie Tuggle recently received a copy of an 18-year-old photograph from his son that he’d never seen before. 
It featured Tuggle’s then-5-year-old boy, Grady Jarrett, wearing a kid-sized version of his No. 58 Atlanta Falcons jersey while doing the “Dirty Bird” dance with his elementary school teammates. 
The old picture made Tuggle smile, remembering back to his own Super Bowl season with the Falcons in 1998. Jarrett, now a 23-year-old starting defensive tackle for Atlanta, is currently preparing to play in the game for the first time. 
MORE SUPER BOWL LI COVERAGE USA TODAY Sports' Super Bowl LI predictions: Patriots or Falcons? 
But just as Jarrett wasn’t in Florida when Tuggle’s team lost to the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXXIII, Tuggle will be home in Alpharetta, Ga., on Sunday, watching the game on a 130-inch big screen. Nagging knee injuries have slowed him down, and he knew going to Houston would mean plenty of walking. Plus, he wants to afford Jarrett the chance to shine, away from the large shadow he'd already cast with the Falcons organization. 
“This is a once-in-a-lifetime chance to play in the largest game on earth. The world is watching. This is his day. This is the Atlanta Falcons' day. It's not my day, it's his day,” Tuggle told USA TODAY Sports in a phone interview. “So I want to sit back and, from a distance — for me personally — I want to let him do his own thing.” 
Tuggle played 14 years as an inside linebacker for Atlanta, retiring after the 2000 season as the franchise’s leading tackler. He’s a member of the Falcons' Ring of Honor, and his picture is displayed prominently at the club's training facility in Flowery Branch, Ga. 
Being drafted by the team for which your father once starred could mean weighty expectations, but Jarrett said he doesn’t feel it. 
“I never felt any kind of pressure to live up to any legacy or anything like that. I've always gone my own way,” Jarrett told USA TODAY Sports. 
He was raised in Conyers, Ga., by his mother, Elisha, and her husband, Grady Jarrett Sr., whom Jarrett calls “dad.” But Tuggle was always part of his life, too, as were his other children, Justin (a former Houston Texans linebacker) and Jessica, who played tennis in college. 
MORE FALCONS COVERAGE Falcons' brotherhood helped assistant Mike McDaniel through alcohol issue 
Jarrett, the youngest of Tuggle’s three children, showed aptitude for football early, even though he was always too big to play with kids his own age. Yet ironically, his size would eventually become an issue for a different reason since Jarrett was regarded as too short to fit the mold of a prototypical defensive tackle. 
Falcons defensive line coach Bryan Cox, an NFL contemporary of Tuggle’s, said Jarrett’s stature (6-feet, 305 pounds) was the biggest reason he fell to the fifth round of the draft in 2015. 
Many teams probably realize it was a mistake to overlook him. 
Despite being relatively light for his position, Jarrett routinely handles double-team blocks and racked up 48 tackles and three sacks from his interior post this season. What he lacks in sheer size, he’s made up for in other areas, including an important lesson he learned while winning two state titles while wrestling in high school. 
“It’s all about leverage. The lower man wins,” Jarrett said. “I wouldn't say I have to make up for anything, it's just what I do differently, as far as using power and quickness. I don’t have any choice but to look at it as a positive.” 
Tuggle and Jarrett spoke by phone before the Falcons departed for Houston, and Tuggle tried to share some advice about what Jarrett could expect in his first Super Bowl. It took until the 12th year of Tuggle’s career to reach this stage, and he wants his son to cherish how special it is to be here just two seasons into his career. So far, that message seems to be sinking in. Jarrett purchased all of his 15 allotted tickets for family members on his mother’s side and is looking forward to their arrival Friday. 
And on Sunday, he’s hoping to get the one thing his father never did: a championship. Nothing would make Tuggle more proud, both as a Falcons alum and a father. 
“I remember the Super Bowl in 1998. We lost, that's all I remember about it. But we get another shot at it, a second time,” Jarrett said. 
“I'm fortunate enough to be on this team that can go and try to finish it off. It’s definitely an exciting time for the people of Atlanta.”

PHOTOS: Falcons' road to Super Bowl LI Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Week 1: Atlanta stumbled out of the gates with a 31-24 loss to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. The Falcons couldn't keep up with Jameis Winston, who threw for 284 yards and four touchdowns. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Week 2: The Falcons outlasted the Oakland Raiders in a wild one thanks to Taylor Gabriel's 8-yard touchdown catch on a tipped pass. Atlanta's defense held on a fourth-and-2 run to help wrap up the first win of the year. Cary Edmondson, USA TODAY Sports Week 3: The depth of the Falcons' offense began to show in a 45-23 win over the New Orleans Saints. Running back Tevin Coleman scored three touchdowns, while Devonta Freeman had 207 yards from scrimmage. Derick E. Hingle, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Week 4: Julio Jones and Matt Ryan both exploded for record days in Atlanta's 48-33 win over the defending NFC-champion Carolina Panthers. Jones finished with a franchise-record 300 receiving yards on 12 catches, falling just short of the NFL record of 336, while Ryan's 503 passing yards were also a team best. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Week 5: Atlanta handed the defending Super Bowl-champion Denver Broncos their first loss despite a less explosive output from its offense. The Falcons rattled rookie Paxton Lynch, who was making his first start at QB for the Broncos, and relied on a steady output from its running backs to seal the win. Ron Chenoy, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Week 6: Dan Quinn's return to Seattle ended in disappointment as the Falcons fell 26-24 to the Seahawks amid controversy. Richard Sherman appeared to interfere with Julio Jones on a deep fourth-and-10 pass in the final two minutes, but officials did not call a penalty. Joe Nicholson, USA TODAY Sports Week 7: A wild comeback left the Falcons stunned in a 33-30 overtime loss to the San Diego Chargers. Atlanta held at 27-10 lead but couldn't hold on, and Josh Lambo kicked the game-winning field goal in overtime. Dale Zanine, USA TODAY Sports Week 8: A 33-32 last-second win over the Green Bay Packers broke Atlanta out of its two-game slide. Mohamed Sanu's 11-yard touchdown catch in the final minute gave the Falcons the final edge. Brett Davis, USA TODAY Sports Week 9: Atlanta avenged its season-opening loss to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers with a 43-28 triumph in the rematch. Matt Ryan threw for 344 yards and four touchdowns to help the Falcons extend their NFC South lead. Reinhold Matay, USA TODAY Sports Week 10: The Falcons entered their bye week on a sour note after tripping in a 24-15 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles. Ryan Mathews ran for two touchdowns and the Falcons had to settle for three field goals. Eric Hartline, USA TODAY Sports Week 12: Taylor Gabriel emerged as the Falcons' newest weapon in a 38-19 win over the Arizona Cardinals. The diminutive receiver and free agent pickup took two short passes for touchdowns and had four receptions for 75 yards. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Week 13: Eric Berry proved to be a worthy foe for the Falcons, as the Kansas City Chiefs escaped with a 29-28 win. Berry returned one interception and became the first player to return a two-point conversion for a score to seal Kansas City's win. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Week 14: Atlanta's defense got in on the scoring in a 42-14 rout of the Los Angeles Rams. Deion Jones returned an interception for a touchdown, and Vic Beasley forced a Jared Goff fumble that he scooped up for a score. Jayne Kamin-Oncea, USA TODAY Sports Week 15: Devonta Freeman took control in the Falcons' 41-13 win over the San Francisco 49ers. Freeman ran for 139 rushing yards and three touchdowns in the romp. Dale Zanine, USA TODAY Sports Week 16: A balanced offensive effort helped the Falcons ease past the Carolina Panthers in a 33-16 win. Atlanta intercepted Cam Newton twice and held him to 198 yards. Bob Donnan, USA TODAY Sports Week 17: The Falcons put the finishing touches on their NFC South title with a 38-32 win over the New Orleans Saints. Atlanta clinched the No. 2 seed in the NFC and a first-round bye with the win. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Divisional round: The Falcons didn't leave their playoff fate to another late call, as they rolled past the Seattle Seahawks for a 36-20 win. Matt Ryan threw for 338 yards and three touchdowns, while the defense threw off Russell Wilson and Seattle's attack. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen NFC Championship Game: Atlanta sealed just its second-ever trip to the Super Bowl with a 44-21 thrashing of the Green Bay Packers. The Falcons' red-hot offense racked up 493 yards, and Aaron Rodgers was held in check after a wild late-season run. Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports Like this topic?
